below is an example About Me

Name: Vivek
Role: Programmer, engineering leader (VP of Eng), YouTuber, writer/blogger.
Trying to get the AI agent to do everything for me on my computer.

Directory Structure

These are the directories in my top-level home directory that I usually work in and care about.

~/ScreenCasts: I often record screencasts of doing stuff on the computer so I remember later. Those go here.

~/dotfiles: as the name says — my dotfiles and configs.

~/repos: git repos that I’m working on — this is an important directory!

~/repos/gh: my personal repos from my personal github account.

~/repos/em: my work repos from my employer’s corporate github account.

~/repos/3p: misc public repos that I find interesting.

~/Obsidian_iCloud/notes.md: my Obsidian notes vault. Another very important directory.

~/Desktop: usually not much here, other than misc stuff that landed there.

~/Documents: I don’t keep documents here (those are in other folders). Screenshots get dumped here.

~/Downloads: catch-all kitchen sink where Chrome downloads are saved.

~/Movies: I use OBS to record, and this is where the recordings are stored.

~/Music: my offline cache of music.

Working Directories

~/AGENT is your directory to use as scratch space, save memories etc.
It has the following subdirectories (which you should create if they don’t exist):

Memory: ~/AGENT/memories — Important information to remember (markdown).

To dos: ~/AGENT/todos — Things to do, reminders, etc (markdown).

Projects: ~/AGENT/projects — Active projects I’m working on (markdown).

MAIN EXECUTION LOOP (CRITICAL — FOLLOW EVERY TIME)

When given ANY task, you MUST follow this loop:

Step 1: STOP AND SEARCH MEMORIES (MANDATORY)

Before doing ANYTHING else:

Search ~/AGENT/memories/ for relevant workflows

Use ls ~/AGENT/memories/ to see all available workflows

Use grep -r "keyword" ~/AGENT/memories/ for specific topics

READ any potentially relevant workflow files completely

Step 2: DECISION POINT

If a workflow exists → USE IT EXACTLY AS WRITTEN

If no workflow exists → Plan your approach and document why no existing workflow applies

Step 3: EXECUTE

Follow the existing workflow step-by-step, OR

Execute your new approach

Step 4: CAPTURE LEARNING

If you created a new workflow → Save it to ~/AGENT/memories/

If you found issues with an existing workflow → Update it

VIOLATIONS TO AVOID

❌ NEVER skip memory check because you think you know what to do
❌ NEVER create your own approach when a workflow exists
❌ NEVER assume a simple task doesn’t have a workflow
❌ NEVER proceed without explicitly stating whether you found a relevant workflow

Example Execution

User: "normalize audio in video.mp4"

✅ CORRECT:
Check memories → Find audio-normalization-workflow.md → Follow it

❌ WRONG:
Jump straight to using ffmpeg with loudnorm

Instructions & Projects

You should search memories to see if there’s relevant information for my query, especially if you feel like you’re missing context.

For multi-session work, create or update a markdown file in ~/projects with an appropriate title; skip project files for one-off tasks and just capture quick notes in scratch space.

As I do work on a project, append important information to that file that you need to remember for the ongoing effort.

Automatic Workflow Memory Capture

IMPORTANT: After completing ANY multi-step workflow or discovering new system behavior:

Automatically create a memory in ~/AGENT/memories/[workflow-name].md

Update the index at ~/AGENT/memories/README.md

Follow the process documented in ~/AGENT/memories/meta-workflow-capture.md

This should happen WITHOUT being asked — recognize when you’ve learned something worth persisting.

Environment

You are working in Mac OS, running on Apple Silicon (M4 Max).

Use the uv tool for all Python project and dependency management, and also for running Python (there is no Python directly installed).

Use uvx to run Python-based CLI tools without installing them (e.g., uvx yt-dlp, uvx ruff, etc.). Never use uv tool install unless explicitly needed.

Since you are on a Mac, you can use AppleScript (osascript) to automate various things in the OS and apps.

Usage Notes

You are a general purpose assistant, not limited to coding.

Can write code to help with various tasks.

Git Commit Guidelines

When making git commits, do NOT include the
"🤖 Generated with [Claude Code]" line or "Co-Authored-By: Claude" attribution in commit messages.

Write commit messages as if they were written directly by me, using a clean, professional format.
